supporting_text: The NAP mentions that combating AMR will require sustained global action across a variety of sectors (Human, Agriculture, Veterinary and environmental) in order to understand, prevent and control resistance.
The NAP includes specific actions in the human health sector, including education and awareness initiatives.
The NAP outlines strategies for optimal use of antimicrobials in animal health.
The NAP includes strategies related to environmental management and waste disposal to reduce AMR impacts.
The NAP addresses the use of antimicrobials in agriculture and food security.
The NAP includes a monitoring and evaluation framework to track progress.
The NAP outlines specific targets for awareness and understanding of AMR by 2022.
The NAP includes quantitative targets for reducing AMR prevalence and optimizing antimicrobial use.
The NAP discusses financing options and budget allocations for AMR activities.
The NAP includes an assessment of budget requirements for various AMR activities.
The NAP mentions the establishment of a multisectoral task force for AMR coordination.
The NAP includes strategies to strengthen legislation and regulations for antimicrobial use.
The NAP includes educational initiatives targeting various audiences, including school curricula.
The NAP outlines public awareness campaigns to combat AMR.
The NAP emphasizes international collaboration and partnerships for AMR initiatives.
The NAP includes strategies for developing surveillance systems and data collection tools for AMR monitoring.
The NAP includes strategies to enhance capacity for detecting and reporting AMR.
The NAP outlines specific prevention strategies, including sanitation and hygiene measures.
The NAP aligns with international standards and guidelines for AMR control.
The NAP includes strategies for regulating the distribution and prescription of antibiotics.
The NAP emphasizes the need for regulations to ensure the rational use of antibiotics.
The NAP includes strategies for participating in international collaborative research for AMR.
